comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: According to the DIA, St. Michael's Church spire was completed in 1902, and I don't see it. County Hall is from 1880.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Hastily amending date to 1902, thank you!

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: What a cracking image! I love all things nautical!

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: An Aeolus class cruiser built in 1890 and sold in 1910 .. www.worldnavalships.com/hms_melampus.htm She seems to have been stationed at Kingstown as a coastguard ship.

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: I have come across this other one on Flickr www.flickr.com/photos/scrumpyrattom/7407340028/

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/vab2009] Looks quite weatherbeaten in the other flickr shot. Thanks a million for the worldnavalships link - priceless image of the sailors waiting to have their grog, and gave me some good tags too!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/vab2009] I have a wry smile on my face as I recall you writing that you would never be able to add to the knowledge here and this time you are leading the charge.  The Melampus did not have a very long life by the looks of things, 20 years seems a short life for an expensive naval vessel.  She looks underpowered and quite old fashioned for a cruiser even in that era.  From the scrumpyrattom link above it would indicate that the shot in Kingstown was taken a lot nearer to 1902 than to 1910, she is in pristine condition in the harbour.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] SOLDIERS Carol, soljers were not the people who worked on ships it was sailors!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] What is scrumpyrattom? And can't think what you mean about soldiers - check the comment... thank the Gods for the "edit" feature!  :D

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: According to Wikipedia, HMS Melampus was an Apollo class protected cruiser built in 1890 and sold in 1910. Diagram here.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] My 1902 is a mistake, I had the wrong church spire! Definitely before 1902, since St. Michaels is not to be seen.

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I found that too - various links said Apollo class or Aeolus class. There were a whole list of ships of that class and Aeolus was one of them so I suspect Apollo class is correct.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Yer on a roll today - making hasty amendments;-))))

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: From all the flags and lovely paintwork, I wouldn't be surprised if this is the Melampus arriving on station at the then Kingstown in 1890.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Pre-dreadnought, so she was presumably scrapped pretty much as soon as turbines replaced triple expansion in capital ships, as her speed:protection:armament balance just wouldn't have cut it in a stand-up fight and the admiralty didn't see a place for commerce raiders or anticipate the need for convoy escorts against submarines.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/vab2009] Not at all! Each and every contribution is very welcome, and very gratefully received.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Wondering how long after launch then, if Melampus came straight to Dublin after launching... From the Irish Times of Tuesday, 20 June 1893:
"His Excellency the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland arrived at Kingstown yesterday on board the Royal mail steamer Ulster. H.M.S. Melampus fired a Royal salute as the mail steamer passed between the pier heads. Lord Houghton proceeded to Westland row by the ordinary mail train, whence he drove to the Viceregal Lodge."
From a very quick Irish Times search, it looks as if the Melampus got about a bit, e.g. visited Plymouth in June 1892...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I don't think the flags help, starting at the front I read Q6M6Y5L9M0 etc. etc. Code of some sort.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The Freeman's journal of Wed Jun 7th1893 has an article titled "The New Kingstown Guardship - Description of HMS Melampus

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I thought those sixes were Ks. I thought numbers were tapered and letters were parallel sided, but it still makes no sense.

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content: AQ lovely old ship picture, thank you for posting.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: According to the Australian newspapers, Prince George, Duke of York (later King George V) was appointed Commander of the 'Melampus' in June 1892 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/8433955 . Hence the flags and Royal Salute in 1893 ?

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: The link in Viv's comment above showing the Melampus in delapidated condition comes from "scrumpy rat Tom" photostream and there is a second shot of the old ship from the stern that gives a slightly different perspective on it. www.flickr.com/photos/scrumpyrattom/7413575428/ Thank you Tom for your fantastic stream.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Not being a Naval expert I could not say for certain but signal hoists were normally from a line on a mast and would have been in a vertical position.  These flags appear to be mere bunting to decorate the ship for the occasion.  While each flag had a letter or number assigned to it some when used in conjunction with others took on specific orders and/or phrases and without a signal book interpretation would be difficult to say the least.  Very nice try though.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
Right, that article [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] mentioned - Freeman's Journal from Wednesday, 7 June 1893:
"The new guardship of the Kingstown district, the Melampus, is expected to arrive on the station to-day, or at latest to-morrow. Owing to unfounded rumours of the arrival of the graceful cruiser great numbers visited the premier township during the past few days, only, however, to be disappointed. The new guardship was commanded by the Duke of York when in temporary commission during last year's manoeuvres...
So this photo has to be post-7 June 1893 then!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
Do I see a No. 7 Tram?

I think we should see the Victoria Memorial here if it was after 1900...

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: These ships were made obsolete by the steam turbine. Here is "Turbinia" which ran riot through the Spithead Navy Review of 1897. www.flickr.com/photos/newcastlelibraries/4081655920/

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The mail steamer at Carlisle pier is still an old paddle steamer. When did those go out of service?

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Looks like the paddle steamer is one of Ulster, Munster, Leinster or Connaught (four smokestacks - two forward, two aft). 1860-1897. www.simplonpc.co.uk/CityofDublin.html Edit: Actually, on second thoughts, it can't be - too many masts. I think there's two steamers one behind the other.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: There appear to be four twin funnelled paddle steamers in all. Maybe a similar class to the S.S. Banshee or maybe they're not mail steamers, despite being tied up at Carlisle Pier. www.anglesey.info/London_and_North_Western_Railways_Shipp...

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] From your City of Dublin SP Co link:

In 1885, they were all given extra accommodation, and improvements to the boilers improved their speeds even further. All four ships then had two funnels only.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] That could well be them, so, limiting the date to 1885-1897. They seem quite similar to those images aside from the funnels.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: Excellent photo, detail on the ship is excellent. Very interesting to see many of the buildings in their original form too.

comment.author: 47044499@N03
comment._content: Great photo.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Steam paddle tugs were still in use in the 1950s. Here is "Conqueror" which I saw tied up each Sunday morning next to the Quayside Market, Newcastle upon Tyne. www.tynetugs.co.uk/conqueror1884.html "Conqueror" was scrapped in 1956.

comment.author: 61703678@N03
comment._content: What a wonderful picture!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: A challenge to the map and GoogleStreetview people - was the photographer on the West or East Pier, or on a boat? And for the Naval Gazers - is that a torpedo tube flap at the bow of the ship? Similar feature on this contemporary photo of HMS 'Torch' - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/3055005210/

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Could be. There's a corresponding one at the stern and they seem to match what look like torpedo tubes on the diagram Niall posted earlier.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Naval gazers;-)))  I like that one.  It looks very oval in shape on Melampus above, that seems an unlikely shape for a torpedo?  It could have been some kind of hatch to give access to the anchors/chains.  On Torch the raised hatch appears round which would be the expected shape for a TT.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] From the wikipedia article on the "Apollo", the ship for which the class was named:

Four 14 in (360 mm) torpedo tube were fitted, two fixed on the stem and stern, and two broadside training tubes on the upper deck aft.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I was just coming back to make "a hasty amendment" on closer examination I notice a hatch/flap at the side of the central protuberance on the bow and then I looked up www.battleships-cruisers.co.uk/aeolus.htm and note that this class of ship was fitted with the four tubes as you describe. My humble apologies for doubting the experts:-(

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] If you look at Niall's diagram, they're round in cross section for most of the length and just flare at the end. (At least, they're probably round - they could be square, or wide and flat and taper to the vertical oblong, but I think the most likely interpretation is round).

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] There is a little daylight between the East side of the Carlisle pier and the Mariners church behind, so I think the photographer is at the end of the East Pier by the lighthouse. Another East Pier shot at nli.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] The only diagramme I've found is this and there is hardly enough information on this to show TT's. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Apollo_class_cruiser_diagrams_... Is there one I am missing perhaps?

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] That's it - upper picture, bow and stern, just below the line running the length of the hull, there's something marked that would match the photos. In the photo you linked earlier showing the ship from the rear, you can see that there's a corresponding oblong port in the stern as well.

comment.author: 7945368@N05
comment._content: I think warships of that era are much more aesthetically pleasing.  There is something about the way that the bow is at an obtuse angle to the water (as opposed to the modern acute angle of modern warships) that is more elegant to the eye.

comment.author: 79597829@N00
comment._content: majestic!

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/joefuz] Those old warships were designed to ram the enemy below the waterline. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naval_ram

comment.author: 85708907@N08
comment._content: Building on waterfront between paddle steamers is the National Yacht Club. From the club's website: "... the present clubhouse was erected in 1870..." - then known as 'Kingstown Royal Harbour Boat Club'. Tags added including various name changes since foundation. www.nyc.ie/about/history/

comment.author: 85708907@N08
